 Welcome to our talk, Red Team Oops, which is truly supposed to be a really light, fun,
entertaining talk.
And then we have a tiny little surprise at the end.
We're doing a small tool release at the end, which hopefully might be useful for somebody
doing offensive security in the crowd.
Yeah, I guess we'll just start off by introducing ourselves.
Awesome.
So, hi, everybody.
My name is Advar Mo.
I work for a company in the U.S. called TrustedSec.
My role there is our Red Teamer, and I've been doing that for the last almost six years
now.
And it's a lot of fun.
Like I do a lot of fun stuff.
So if you've heard my name before, it's probably because of the Lolbass project.
That's probably the thing I've contributed to that has made the biggest impact.
I'm also a Microsoft security MVP.
I work out of Norway.
I love bad dad jokes and dry humor.
So yeah, that's me.
My name is Børge Langvik.
I go by the alias Flangvik online.
I do really shitty streams.
I produce some YouTube content.
I go around and hold presentations like this.
And I work for Covert.
I used to work with Advar at TrustedSec.
The dad jokes really got to me, so I had to quit.
It was bad.
Depression sucks.
No, it was a joke, obviously, but yeah.
So our relation, let's just move into the next slide here.
Our relation is that me and Advar used to be coworkers, so we worked together for many
years now.
And while working together, we performed what's called Red Team operations, or what we refer
to internally at TrustedSec as Adversarial Attack Simulations, AAS.
I'm assuming sort of everybody knows what the Red Team mission is, but just to give
a short overview so everybody is familiar with that term, it's targeted security testing
over typically a lengthier period of time, like six weeks plus, where attackers like
me and Advar try to breach a perimeter of your organization and reach a goal.
So the goal might be to get access to a server, might be to get access on some sort of piece
of information or compromised account, whatnot, and that's sort of where this whole talk revolves
around these operations that we performed.
So typical war stories, which are just people bragging about what cool stuff they did during
engagements, they have a positive note, meaning that we did this, we were successful, we owned,
we got out, we didn't get detected, whatnot.
This talk is not that.
This talk is about all the times we fucked up.
So this is the talk where we basically show our weak spots.
We show, we're really vulnerable up here, talking about all the times we made mistakes
because you know what?
We make big, fat mistakes sometimes as well, and I think it's interesting to talk about
them so we all can learn from them.
Mistakes.
Mistakes.
I was a mistake.
Quitting was a mistake.
Oh, wow.
Microphone is on there.
Okay.
So we're going to talk about all the lessons learned during these mistakes and all the
TTPs found.
So typically at the end of these mistakes, we want to try to turn it into something positive.
Maybe we found some interesting research in our struggles.
Maybe we stumbled into something that made it worthwhile, right?
Not all the stories we'll be talking about today will end with a TTP, but at least the
last one will end with a TTP and a tool release for you guys.
It's a tiny one, so don't get all too excited, but it's fun nonetheless.
And also remember that these stories are kind of old as well.
Yes.
These are, you know, for security reasons or NDAs, what not, jail.
We don't want to talk about what we did last year, so these are like a couple of years
old, but they're still relevant.
Not ancient or anything like that.
I also want to say that the dynamic here is that we're going to go back and forth telling
stories and then, yeah, we'll see what happens.
Hopefully it's entertaining.
So Oduar, why don't you kick it off?
Okay.
Lean back and enjoy story time, guys.
All right.
So we had a lot of help from AI.
I can't use real images, but that is me, the one with the hoodie and the business suit.
So this story begins, I had a kickoff call with a client and this client had done a lot
of investment in training the users for phishing.
So he wanted me to actually do as much phishing as possible.
So like our normal typical red team assignments are that we try to get in like the first half
of the engagement.
If we are not succeeding in that, either doing externally exploiting or phishing, we tend
to kind of suggest that we pivot to an assume breach.
Like they detonate a payload, we get access, and we work from there because it's the best
use of time.
We don't want to waste as much time.
But this customer, all he was talking about was phishing, phishing, phishing, phishing,
phishing during the entire kickoff call.
So apparently he didn't want to do assume breach.
That was not on the table.
So he said either you get in externally, preferably by phishing, or that's it.
That's your engagement.
Like that's what you're supposed to do on this engagement.
And while he was talking about phish, phish, phish, all I could see in my head was this
for some reason.
I was like, phish.
So okay.
The engagement starts.
Please remember, this was a while back.
This was, I mean, I worked for Sussex for six years now.
This was probably within my first year.
I wasn't really advanced at this point.
I created a macro.
The pretext was that we sent out a phishing pretext where there was new security policies
in place.
So the user had to comply to these policies.
So in order to comply, they had to open my Word document, which had like a copied URL,
copyright text, something.
That made no sense.
But it looked like a policy.
It had two buttons, agree or disagree.
But the trick I did was that I disabled the buttons.
And in order for them to work, they had to enable the macros for them to be clickable.
And I wrote that in the pretext as well.
I mean, I felt it was pretty clever, kind of fun.
So sent that away to like 10, 15 users.
I targeted like employees that hadn't worked there for a long time.
Like people that just started like within the last year.
Because normally they would like fall for things like this.
Because they want to be compliant.
They want to be doing everything correctly.
So sent that away.
And I got a shell.
Like I got like a notification on my phone.
And I was super excited.
I mean, remember, this was early on in my career.
And I was like, yeah, this, I'm awesome.
I'm the best in the world.
You know the feeling.
So yeah.
I got shell from two users.
And I was so excited that my monitor was turned the wrong way apparently.
I kind of forgot to turn it around.
Go figure.
But looking closely into like the user names and stuff, I noticed, well, after turning
my screen, of course, I noticed that it was Joe and user.
Yeah.
For those that are familiar with sending out fishes, if you end up in a sandbox or something
similar, when they detonate the payload, you will often see the user Joe or the name user
or admin or stuff like that.
So of course, I understood that, OK, this was a sandbox, god damn it.
So I didn't feel so cool after that.
But OK, let's do another fish.
This time, this was before I knew about Evil Jinx.

I bought or we had like a domain that looked similar to Microsoft's.

You need to click here to view it.

They clicked.
And when they clicked, they would go to this portal.

Again, I got credentials.

OK, this time, this is real.
I'm going to log into the cloud or the VPN.
I'm going to pawn them properly.

So that's what I got.
Yeah, lucky me, huh?
So did a crying face again, again, working a lot of late hours, getting tired, getting

Did a fish once more, a new pretext, and this pretext I don't even want to talk about because
it was so dumb written.
It didn't work.
It was made fun of by the blue team again.
And also another failed fish.
And at this point in time, I'm like, I'm super exhausted.
I mean, I used all my creativity, and my rage is just through the roof.
I mean, I'm so mad.
Like, this is not for me.
Maybe I should change career.

I mean, maybe I'm not cut out for this red team stuff.
Maybe I'm stupid.
I'm probably stupid.
I can't fish even.
So I decided to go, and now we're moving into, like, last week.
So I've been fishing, like, five, six weeks in a row, and I'm, like, super exhausted as
well.
Last fish, I decided to go for something I really didn't think would work.
But I created, like, a HTA kind of payload that would fire a survey and sent it from
a domain that looked like typical, like, survey monkey kind of domain thing.
And this time I didn't care to even look at what users I was targeting.
I basically just picked ten people at random.
I didn't even care, to be honest.

Sent it away.
And to my big surprise, I actually got a shell this time.
Like, for real.
I got a shell.

So good.
I even told my wife.
I did it.
So good job.

Establish persistence.

I work my ass off.

Did everything.

As you do.

No.

Okay.

No.

Okay.
Okay.

That happens.

It's unlikely.

Especially on a Wednesday.
Or maybe the kid got sick.
I don't know.
So I decided to wait until Thursday.
Thursday comes around.
And no shell.
And I was, like, come on.
So I started to look at stuff.
Like I, for instance, I looked at all the files I downloaded and I thought to myself,
maybe I should check out the survey.

I'll let you guys read it.
Yeah.
That's red team life.
I thought we were supposed to leak my survey.
That's mean.
It was you.
So you're carrying it.
I'm kidding.
I'm kidding.
Yeah.
So my feelings.
Explained.
Okay.
So while I was writing the report after this complete failure, I started to think how I
failed so many times.
And at this stage, I was, like, there must be a better way to do this.
And I started to get creative.
I must admit, I was pretty proud of myself.
I'm not sure if you had this, but you wake up with this brilliant idea all of a sudden.
I had one of those moments.
And prior to working at TrustedSec, I worked as an infrastructure consultant.
So I had done a lot of, like, Microsoft stuff.
And I got a super idea.
I actually got an idea.
So the idea was that I could use Azure information protection going forward.
This is nothing new now, but back in the day, it was, like, something nobody has done before.
So what it does with Azure information protection, since everybody's in the cloud now, this is
super easy to use.
And you can, like, encrypt a document or an email to a specific user, and only that user
at the organization can open that attachment.
So imagine the pain for a blue teamer trying to figure this one out.
Because they actually have to take the password for that user and log in as that user into
the inbox and pull out the payload.
So I was super excited about finding out this.
All of this came from having failed, like, five, six times on this engagement.
If you're interested in learning more about this, there's, like, a blog post at TrustedSec.
There's also a talk at DerbyCon that we did about this topic.
But I thought it was pretty cool at the time.
So what did we learn?
Persistency pays off, kind of.
I got a shell, but it was the kind of wrong shell or the wrong person.
And when you are targeting, make sure to check, like, their profile and stuff.
And maybe they're going to work somewhere else.
It's worth to check just their LinkedIn or other things.
And when you meet a lot of resistance and you fail over and over and over and over again,
I at least get very creative in terms of finding out new stuff.
Okay.
That was my first story.
Do you want to take it, Melvin?

Oh, Lord, did I have plans for what I wanted to do.
So I'll talk you through the initial payload that I wanted to do against this customer.
This was more of a typical Red Team, where you have a portion of the Red Team to OSINT,
you have a portion of the Red Team for social engineering, and then you pivot into a Zoom

So this was supposed to be my magical payload.
And to walk through that, it's as dumb as an Excel macro dropping a malicious DLL, which
is triggering a DLL side-loading attack in Teams.
This was very common at the time, and it has since been very common.
I think it's dead now with the new version of Teams, but yeah.
So this was the attack.
The nice thing about this attack is that I'm not running some weird PowerShell stager,

is hunky-dory.
So that was the plan.
I started to learn Photoshop and CSS.
So this is the email that I'm sending the client.
I pretended to be what was called the Microsoft Information Protection at the time, which
is not the same as the email protection, but I think it was an extension to the Office

And I pretended to be that, and I told a bunch of employees that, hey, you need to click

If you click that button, I used the URI scheme to automatically open an Excel document from

Me?

I sent it, right?

I got my payload.
I sent it.

And that is not me, it's me failing, but that is because Teams is a bunch of smaller applications
running just like Chrome or modern browsers, right?
And I didn't have anything to stop that.
I didn't have a process mutex like I should have had on that thread, right?
So it just kept spawning, kept spawning, kept spawning.
Every time somebody downloaded a document, I would get 20 shells back over a short period
of time from that machine.
Now that was great, right?
You can't get too much initial access.
It's not what could possibly, you know, what else could have gone wrong here?
I got a bunch of shells, right?
It's not stealthy.
It's dumb, but I got a bunch of shells.
Well, Melvin wanted to be really clever when he created this config.
At the time, we were using Cobalt Strike, and in the config for this payload, I thought,
you know what?
Let's be really stealthy.
Let's only call back once every two hours.
That's clever.
Or four hours.
But I had put the sleep to 14 million milliseconds.

milliseconds.
They launch and die all the time.
So I would get the shell unable to queue a task.
It would die.
It would be like a constant circle of temptation.
Initial access, nope.
Initial access, nope.
Initial access, nope.

It's the ultimate teaser.
Yes, it is.
This was my first gig.
I was supposed to impress someone.
You did.
You did.
New record.
And so I started thinking, how am I going to remedy this situation?
So I looked at the documentation for Cobalt Strike, and I looked at these event hooks,
which you can create up in an aggressor script, and then these can be triggered when the beacon
checks in or the initial callback for the beacon.
The issue with all of these is that they still won't queue the task until the task
won't be accepted by the beacon before the next return, and by the next return, the team's
process will be dead.
So the end of story for this one is that I ended up changing, and luckily for me, the
Excel macro that I deployed fetched the DLL from a remote resource, so I quickly replaced
that DLL with a DLL that didn't sleep for 14 million milliseconds and that did have
a process mutex in order to prevent millions of calls, tens of twenties of callbacks.
And that worked, and luckily somebody else clicked the DLL and I definitely never got
that initial access I wanted on the first few machines, but a lot of people clicked
and that saved me, and let's just say I didn't call this out in the report.
I didn't mention this specifically, other than that we had compromised an extra machine
very briefly.

Yes, this is a story that comes up.

Well, always check your payload configuration before hitting send.
This sounds dumb.
It is dumb.
I'm dumb, but just do it, okay?
Also replicating and playing out the initial access scenario in the lab probably is always

After this, I have gone to extra lengths getting information from the client in order to properly

So during most engagements you want to key your payload, you want to make sure it's unable

Great.

So I had a meeting with a client, a kickoff call, typically what's referred to, where
we discussed the definitions of the engagement and technical details and whatnot.
And this client was very specific in that they wanted us to fish with QR codes.
And I see a lot of people scanning the QR code.
I do that.
And this is really weird.
And it fooled my senses immediately.
Why is this client being very specific about the techniques being used?
Yes, it happens sometimes.
But most of the time, the client is more specific about what they want to achieve during engagement,
what values, what goal we want to reach.
And not necessarily what techniques they want specifically tested.
So obviously, I took the bait and I started doing QR code fishing.
And it was a nightmare.
My emails never got through.
If some of them got through, it got immediately reported and detected.
It was obvious that this client had definitely done their research and specifically asked
me to do fishing using QR codes in order to make me look like a fool or at least get a
good stamp on that test.
And you forgot to turn the screen on.
Yes, I also forgot to turn the screen on this one.
I'm a dumb dumb.
Okay.
So that started my creative thinking process.
Okay, let's do some really basic research and let's just do Google.
Okay, how do these companies detect QR codes in fishing emails?
And I found this rather interesting blog post by a guy called Liam Jones from Stripeit.
And he has this query that I'm assuming he probably uses with Microsoft Sentinel, depending
how much money he wants to give to Microsoft every month.
And it's a basic query to pull out all potentially untrusted emails coming inbound that has an
image attached.
Now, there's a couple of mistakes in this one.
The big one being that there's way more image types than PNG, JPEG, and SVG, you know, GIF,
